H0.text: The woodpecker population in a forest area would produce more offspring if a housing development is built in that area.

H1.text: They would change the color of their feathers if a housing development is built in the forest area where the woodpecker population resides.

H2.text: They would experience a decrease in available food if a housing development is built in the forest area.

H3.text: They would experience a decrease in competition if a housing development is built in the forest area, affecting the woodpecker population.

A4.text: Forest fragmentation reduces food resources and habitat sources for animals thus splitting these species apart.

A5.text: Forest patches that are smaller or more isolated will lose species faster than those that are larger or less isolated.

A6.text: Vegetation is often completely removed during housing development, obliterating native species in the area.

A7.text: Urban environments also favor fast-reproducing, mobile species, contributing to biotic homogenization and the global decline of ecological uniqueness.

A8.text: Species abundance populations are reduced due to the reduced fragmented area of habitat.
